awd_titl_txt: Laser Plasma Interactions in MegaGauss Magnetic Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
Stars, galaxies, and nebulae in the universe consist of matter in a plasma state.  Magnetic fields dramatically impact properties of plasma. Magnetic fields are thought to be responsible for catastrophic cosmic events such as generation of super-strong x-ray bursts by collapsing stars and explosion of solar flares.  Understanding of plasma in strong magnetic fields is important for astrophysics, basic plasma physics, and energy and national defense applications. A unique combination of the Mega-Ampere current generator and powerful short-pulse laser at the University of Nevada, Reno allows to investigate plasmas in magnetic fields that are millions of times stronger that the Earth's magnetic field.  In this project, the impact of strong magnetic fields on high-energy beams of electrons, and proton beams generated by the powerful laser in a solid target will be studied.  In collaboration with the University of Rochester, three graduate students will be trained and will perform experimental and theoretical work.

Electron transport in the solid laser target will be studied in the axial magnetic field of 1-1.5 MGauss. The pulsed power generator provides well measured and controlled magnetic fields. Coherent transient radiation from the rear side of the target will illuminate a spot of the electron beam and indicate a guiding and focusing effect in the magnetic field. Enhanced generation of proton beams in the external magnetic field will be studied with the same experimental configuration combining laser and pulsed power capabilities. A "proof of principle" experiment will be performed at the magnetic field of ~1.5 MGauss. The experimental program will be supported by simulations of electron and proton beams in a strong longitudinal magnetic field using hybrid particle-in-cell codes.  Results of the project are relevant to the "fast ignition" approach to inertial confinement fusion and for medical applications.  This project is jointly funded by the Division of Physics and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project were to study the laser-driven high-energy particles guided in strong Mega-gauss (million gauss, MG) magnetic fields. MG magnetic fields are well known in astrophysical objects such as magnetic White Dwarf stars. We developed methods for generating MG magnetic fields on a university-scale pulsed power machine. The magnetic fields have been characterised using Faraday rotation diagnostics.

    Beams of fast electrons were generated by a 50 Terawatt laser in solid targets. High-energy electrons can be used in the ?fast Ignition? approach for fusion. In this concept, collimated electron beams can heate the ?hot spot? in a fusion capsule that has been preheated by a megajoul laser.

    A new laser-pulsed power experimental platform has been developed at the University of Nevada, Reno to study the possibility of guiding electron beams in laser targets by strong magnetic fields. The electron beam was studied using optical coherent transition radiation generated by electrons on the rear side of the target. 92 shots with the 50 TW laser and the 1 MA pulsed power machine were carried out.

    Two new physical effect were discovered in the experiments. We found that the plasma on the CH plastic target consist of filaments with a diameter of 10-20 um, as shown in Figure 1. This effect is important for understanding the details of the interaction of ultra-shot laser radiation with plasmas.

We also found suppression of laser-generated fast electrons on solid targets in strong magnetic fields. The suppression of the generation of fast electrons is a result of the specific shape of the pre-plasma on the laser target. This effect is important for the ?fast ignition? concept.

   Three graduate students received grant support and were trained in High Energy Density Physics. One student received an MS dgeree, the other a PhD.

    The developed experimental platform can be used for various plasma studies in strong magnetic fields up to 4 MG. This research could have an impact on various fields, including astrophysics, basic physics, and fusion research.
